msContents.summary: Fragments which may come from a single volume, a poetic anthology. See A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), pp. 281-330, at p. 283. The authorship of many items is uncertain: attributions are discussed in the notes to individual items. The leaves were cut at the top, bottom or at the outer margin and show signs of having once been used as pastedowns. As a result, significant portions of the texts are now missing. The old foliation, running from 1 to 16, was rearranged in accordance with J. H. Mozley, 'Some Notes on Lat. misc. d. 15', Bodleian Quarterly Record 7 (1932), pp. 133-138 and now runs in the following order: 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 10, 11v-11r, 16, 7, 8, 5, 6, 12, 13v-13r, 14, 15. The following description refers to the old foliation.

msItem.locus: (fol. 1r col. a – col. b line 18)
msItem.incipit: Nec sterilis fraudetfraudat semina messe labor
msItem.explicit: Et meritum populo teste perorat honor
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning.
As a result of trimming, c. 4 lines are missing at the top of columns a and b.
56 verses remain.
msItem.bibl: Printed in: J. H. Mozley, 'Some unprinted fragments of Matthew of Vendôme (?): A Description of the Bodleian MS Misc. Lat. D. 15', Studi medievali N.S. 6 (1933), pp. 208-238, at pp. 222-223 (no. II).

msItem.locus: (fols. 1r col. b line 19 – 4v col. a line 34)
msItem.author: Guilelmus Blesensis
msItem.title: Alda
msItem.incipit: Dum parit Alda perit; Ulfus pro conjuge natam
msItem.explicit: Et deceptoris sponsa fit Alda sui.
msItem.note: As a result of trimming, the following verses (or part of verses) are missing: verses 20-24, 62-65 (fol. 1v); the ends of verses 146-185 (fol. 2r); the beginning of verses 186-232 (fol. 2v); verses 314-316, the ends of verses 317-354, verses 355-358 (fol. 3r); the ends of verses 359-396, verses 397-400 and 442-445 (fol. 3v); verses 446 (partly legible), 489-490 and the ends of verses 491-530 (fol. 4r); verses 531-532 and the beginnings of verses 533-566 (fol. 4v).

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Commedie latine del XII e XIII secolo, ed. Ferruccio Bertini, vol. VI, Pubblicazioni dell'Istituto di filologia classica dell'Università di Genova, 1998, pp. 11-109, which lists previous editions. Manuscript B.

msItem.locus: (fols. 4v col. a line 35 – 4v col. b)
msItem.title: Accusations of a husband against his wife
msItem.incipit: Vos, sancti patres, moueat mea questio uestrum
msItem.explicit: Quid dedit hospicium inueni non abnegat uxor
msItem.note: As a result of trimming, the beginning of the first five verses (fol. 4v col. a) are missing, and c. 4 lines are missing at the top of column b.
Imperfect at the end.

The first two verses were printed in: A. Boutémy, 'Recherches sur le 'Floridus Aspectus' III Pièces inédites ou peu connues du MS. 1136 de l'Arsenal', Latomus 8 (1949), pp. 283-301, at p. 292 (first verses of a poem titled Causa inter pauperem et diuitem de apibus).

The third line ('Rarius in terris nihil est quam femina recti') marks the beginning of the Versus de sponso adversus sponsam suam printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1453. The text differs substantially from the PL edition. Manitius 3.830 suggests that the poem beg. 'Rarius in terris...' belongs to Petrus Riga's Floridus aspectus. For a proposed attribution to Petrus Riga, see also: A. Boutémy, 'Recherches sur le Floridus Aspectus de Pierre le Rigge', Le Moyen Age 54 (1948), pp. 89-112.
msItem.bibl: WIC 16419 ('Rarius in terris...'). 'Vos sancti patres...' not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 9r col. a lines 1–21)
msItem.note: For the rubric, Mozley (1933) proposes 'conquestio cleri' or 'querimonia cleri'.
msItem.incipit: Militat et sepelit nominis umbra malum
msItem.explicit: Regno subis, sordes floreo, mando uenis.
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning.

msItem.locus: (fol. 9r col. a lines 22– 9v col. b line 27)
msItem.incipit: Flagitat a uobis recipi mendica supellex
msItem.explicit: His medanturmedeatur, conpaciatur uestra potestas.
msItem.note: As a result of trimming, verses are missing at the top of fol. 9r-v.
Further marginal rubrics: 'responsio (matris)', 'de horeste'.
Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 9v col. b lines 28–37)
msItem.incipit: Uexillum fidei, populi candela, sophie
msItem.explicit: Cum mentita fuit forma perisse uirum
msItem.note: 10 verses
Proposed attribution to Petrus Riga, as part of his Floridus aspectus. See Hauréau, Notices et Extraits 31.1, p. 96.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: A. Boutémy, 'Recherches sur le 'Floridus Aspectus' III Pièces inédites ou peu connues du MS. 1136 de l'Arsenal', Latomus 8 (1949), pp. 283-301 at p. 300.

msItem.locus: (fols. 9v col. b line 38 – 10r col. a line 24)
msItem.title: De tribus hominis mansionibus
msItem.incipit: Trina domus iusto est, fit in aere prima, secunda
msItem.explicit: Primi culpa patris gratia sola dei
msItem.note: 26 verses
msItem.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1316.
msItem.note: For other copies of the text: C. Fierville, 'Notices et extraits des manuscrits de la bibliothèque de Saint-Omer nos 115 et 710', in: Notices et extraits 31, pp. 49-156; A. Boutémy, 'Recherches sur le 'Floridus Aspectus' II Analyse du manuscrit 1136 de la Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal', Latomus 8 (1949), pp. 159-168.

msItem.locus: (fol. 10r col. a line 25 – col. b line 4)
msItem.title: De Anglia et eius principe
msItem.incipit: Anglia nunc humilis, terrarum gloria quondam
msItem.explicit: Cum sit nature ueneris furor iste rebellis
msItem.note: 19 verses remain. Due to trimming, c. 3 verses are missing at the end of column a.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1444. The final two verses ('Quam prauus mos est pueros preferre puellis / Cum sit nature ueneris furor iste rebellis') are the first two lines of a poem printed in Neues Archiv, 18 (1892), pp. 519-520.
WIC 1014 ('Anglia nunc humilis...'); WIC 15159 ('Quam prauus mos...').

msItem.locus: (fols. 10r col. b line 5 – 10v col. b line 6)
msItem.title: De excidio Troiae versus
msItem.incipit: Pergama flere uolo, fato Danais data solo
msItem.explicit: Femina fatalis, femina digna malis
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the following distichs (or parts of distichs) are missing: the ends of distichs 1-18(1), distichs 18(2)-19 (fol. 10r); the beginnings of distichs 20-41(1), and distichs 41(2)-42 (fol. 10v).

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Carmina Burana No. 101 (1/2, pp. 139–60) (with discussion of relationship between this poem and ‘Uiribus arte’). Manuscript O10.
WIC 13985 ('Pergama flere volo Grecis fato data solo').

msItem.locus: (fol. 10v col. b line 7 – 11v col. a line 20)
msItem.incipit: Ardet amore Paris, Troianis immolat aris
msItem.explicit: Regna nupsit ei uirgo favore dei.
msItem.note: Due to trimming, c. 3 verses are missing at the end of fol. 10v col. b, as well as the beginnings of all verses on fol. 11v col. a.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Carmina Burana No. 102 (1/2, pp. 160-165). Manuscript O.

msItem.locus: (fol. 11v col. a line 21 – fol. 11r col. b line 8)
msItem.title: Poem on the fall of Troy
msItem.incipit: Uiribus, arte minis, Danaum data Troia ruinis
msItem.explicit: Paxque reformatur, dum tibi nupta datur.
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the beginnings of all verses on fol. 11v col. a are missing, as well as a few verses at the end of fol. 11v col. a and b, and two verses at the end of fol. 11r col. a.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1451 and in The Oxford book of medieval latin verse, ed. S. Gaselee (Oxford, 1946), no. 65, p. 121.

msItem.locus: (fols. 11r col. b line 9 – 16v col. b (end))
msItem.title: Causa Aiacis et Ulixis II
msItem.incipit: Sernat ubi uirtus reddolet prestancia seuit
msItem.explicit: Nectit, iter uobis officiale paro.
msItem.note: Marginal rubric 'responsio ulixis' at fol. 16v.

Verses 25-26 are omitted. Due to trimming, the following are missing: verses 35-39 (end of fol. 11r col. b and beg. of fol. 16r col. a), verses 79-81 (top of fol. 16r col. b), verses 121-123 (top of fol. 16v col. a), the beginning of verses 124-162 (fol. 16v) and verses 163-165 (top of fol. 16v col. a). Imperfect at the end (the 414-line text stops at verse 204).
The incipit reads 'Vernat' in the printed edition.
Schmidt: a possible attribution to one of Matthew, of Vendôme's students.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Paul Gerhard Schmidt, "'Causa Aiacis et Ulixis I-II'. Zwei ovidianische Streitgedichte des Mittelalters", Mittellateinisches Jahrbuch 1 (1964), pp. 100-132 at p. 120-132. Manuscript B.

msItem.locus: (fol. 7r col. a – col. b line 14)
msItem.title: Miles gloriosus
msItem.incipit: restituit sumptus fortis amica fides
msItem.explicit: Illis uer animi milla perurit hyemps
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning: only verses 310-366 remain.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: "Miles gloriosus", ed. and trans. Robert Baschet, in: La 'Comédie' latine en France au xiie siècle (Paris, 1931), vol. i, pp. 196-210.
Edited in: "Miles gloriosus", ed. Silvana Pareto, Commedie latine del XII e XIII secolo, IV (1983), pp. 11-93. Manuscript Bd.
WIC 4732 for the first verse of the poem ('Dona Dionee dextre superantia votum').

msItem.note: Previously thought to be a work by Matthew, of Vendôme; Silvana Pareto proposes an attribution to Arnulf of Orléans. See also Arnolfo di Orléans, Lidia, in: ed. I. Gualandri and G. Orlandi, Commedie latine del XII e XIII secolo, VI (1998), pp. 113-204.

msItem.locus: (fols. 7r col. b line 15 – 8v col. a line 3)
msItem.author: Petrus Riga (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Hactenus arrisit Susana gratia forme
msItem.explicit: ... necem
msItem.note: Marginal rubric 'defensio susanne per Danielem' at fol. 7v.
Due to trimming, the ends of the verses on col. 8r col. b and the beginning of verses on fol. 8v col. a are missing.
msItem.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1287. Printed in Hauréau, Notices et Extraits 29.2, pp. 352-358 where it is attributed to Peter Riga. Printed in Mozley, 'Susanna and the Elders: Three medieval poems', in: Studi medievali 3 (1930), 27-52 at pp. 36-41 (poem 1a).
msItem.note: According to Beichner, the text belongs to a group of poems composed independently which circulated as part of Peter Riga's Floridus aspectus, and were later incorporated into his Aurora: Petri Rigae Biblia versificata, ed. Beichner (Notre Dame, 1965), p. xv.

msItem.locus: (fol. 8v col. a line 4 – fol. 5r col. b line 4)
msItem.author: Petrus Riga
msItem.title: Passio sanctae Agnetis
msItem.incipit: Agnes sacra sui pennam scriptoris inauret
msItem.explicit: virtutum titulis uendicat Agna sibi
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the beginning of verses in col. a at fol. 8v are missing, and the first few verses at fol. 5r are also missing in col. a and col. b.
Approximately 167 verses are missing between the end of fol. 8v and the beginning of fol. 5r: the equivalent of one missing sheet in this location.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1307. Printed in: Le "Mathematicus" de Bernard Silvestris et la "Passio sanctæ Agnetis" de Pierre Riga, ed. B. Hauréau (Paris, 1895) where it is attributed to Petrus Riga. Printed in J. Werner, Beiträge zur Kunde der lateinische Literatur des Mittelalters (Aarau, 1905), pp. 65–74.
WIC 696.

msItem.locus: (fol. 5r col. b line 5 – fol. 6v (end))
msItem.author: Marbode, Bishop of Rennes
msItem.title: Life of St Lawrence
msItem.incipit: A decimo tentus, gladioque furente peremptus
msItem.explicit: Quod facis in tenebris uulgabit fama celebris
msItem.note: imperfect at the end.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with works of Marbode, PL 171.1607.
WIC 21.

msItem.locus: (fol. 12r col. a lines 2–25)
msItem.incipit: nature contenta bonis non arte decorem
msItem.explicit: uultum dum uoti nescit habere modummoram
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning.

Mozley (1932) advances the hypothesis that this may be Matthew, of Vendôme's lost work, Callisto (?) , albeit with reservations (Mozley (1933)). See E. Faral, Les arts poétiques du XIIe et du XIIIe siècle (Paris, 1924), pp. 7-9.
msItem.bibl: Poem printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 229-230 (no. IX).

msItem.locus: (fol. 12r col. a line 26 – col. b line 13)
msItem.incipit: Uexatur ratio pietas afflicta pudorem
msItem.explicit: tela cucullatus sero reflectit iter
msItem.bibl: Poem printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 230-231 (no. X).
msItem.note: Mozley (1933) suggests that this poem may be attributable to Matthew, of Vendôme.
Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 12r col. b line 14 – fol. 12v col. a line 10)
msItem.incipit: consilium petit in medium defectus amoris
msItem.explicit: inproba terra iace Gallia uicta tace.
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the following verses or parts of verses are missing: the ends of verses on fol. 12r col. b, one or several verses at the top of fol. 12v col. a and the beginnings of the all verses at fol. 12v col. a.
msItem.bibl: Poem printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 231-232 (no. XI).
msItem.note: Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 12v col. a line 11 – fol. 12v col. b)
msItem.title: Altercatio araneae et muscae
msItem.incipit: In mediis reor esse bonis quod carpere dotes
msItem.explicit: In puero redoletreddet in leuitate statum.
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the following verses or parts of verses are missing: the beginnings of all verses at fol. 12va, and one or several verses at the top of fol. 12v col. b.
Marginal rubrics at fol. 12v col. b line 2 ('responsio musce') and col. b line 31 ('iudicum').
msItem.bibl: Poem printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 232-234 (no. XII).
msItem.note: Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 13v col. a – fol. 13v col. b line 19)
msItem.author: Matthew, of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (extract: 1.57-58)
msItem.incipit: Corporee dotes effigiale bonum
msItem.explicit: Reciprocos digitos esse podagra pedes.
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning. The text starts at 1.57, v. 12.
Due to trimming, the following verses or parts of verses are missing: the beginnings of 1.57, verses 12-24; the beginnings of 1.58, verses 1-25; and the entirety of 1.58, verses 26-29.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 130-132.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 84-88. Manuscript N.

WIC 16681 for the first verse of section 1.57 of the Ars versificatoria ('Respondent ebori dentes, frons libera lacti'); WIC 5615 for the first verse of section 1.58 of the Ars versificatoria ('Est Beroe rerum scabies, lex livida, vultu').

msItem.locus: (fol. 13v col. b line 20–35)
msItem.author: Matthew, of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (extract: 1.111)
msItem.incipit: Nature studium locus est, quo ueris habundant
msItem.explicit: Uernat, odoratus deliciosa comes.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: PL 205.985; Matthaei Vindocinencis, Ars versificatoria, Louis Bourgain (Paris, 1879), pp. 41-42; ed. in part in Faral, Les arts poétiques, p. 148; printed in Mozley (1933), pp. 208-238, at p. 229 (no. VII).
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), p. 116. Manuscript N.

msItem.locus: (fol. 13v col.b line 36 – fol. 13r col. a line 2)
msItem.incipit: Officio triplici tueor tria, sunt peritura
msItem.explicit: Sum ne lux lumen uiolet ne cera uolumen.
msItem.note: The three verses at the end of fol. 13v and the two verses at the top of fol. 13r were printed as a four-verse poem by Mozley. However, the third line is repeated at the top of fol. 13r. Considering that the top of fol. 13 has been trimmed, that the second iteration of the verse "Uis mea procurat...' on fol. 13r is preceded by a paragraphus mark and is accompanied by a rubric ('uel sic'), it is possible that there were originally two poems on a similar theme.
msItem.bibl: Printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 208-238, at p. 229 (part of no. VIII).
msItem.note: Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 13r col. a lines 3–4)
msItem.incipit: Paupere ditato grauius nichil esse putato / Paupere nil peius dum sors res ampliat eius.
msItem.note: Two verses (transcribed in full).
msItem.bibl: Printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 208-238, at p. 229 (part of no. VIII).
msItem.note: Not in WIC.

msItem.locus: (fol. 13r col. a lines 5–26)
msItem.author: Matthew, of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (extract: 1.107-108, verses only).
msItem.incipit: Uer roseum tenero lasciuit flore, laborat
msItem.explicit: Uergit ad occasum languidiore rota.
msItem.note: 22 verses
Partially legible marginal rubrics for some of the verses.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 146-147.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 113-115. Manuscript N.

msItem.locus: (fol. 13r col. a line 27 – col. b)
msItem.incipit: In dominos dominatur amor, domat omnia, fortes
msItem.explicit: crescit honor forme numero crescente bonorum
msItem.note: A few verses are missing at the beginning of col. b and many verses in col. b are missing their endings, due to trimming.
Partially legible marginal rubrics for some of the verses.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 227-228 (no. VI).
Not in WIC.

msItem.note: Possible attribution to Matthew, of Vendôme: Mozley (1933).

msItem.locus: (fol. 14r col. a, line 1 – col. b line 6)
msItem.incipit: si taceam, fidei sunt fracta repagula, regnant
msItem.explicit: carmina castigans nostra Talia tacet
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning (Mozley: 4 lines lost at the beginning, and 4 lines lost at the top of col. b).
12 verses.

msItem.locus: (fol. 14r col. b line 7 – fol. 14v (end of col. b))
msItem.title: An altercation between Grammar and logic (?) (poem)
msItem.incipit: Est manus interpres latinitantis criminis, huius
msItem.explicit: Prouocat in listes perniciosa soror.
msItem.note: 116 verses remain.
Marginal rubric at fol. 14v col. b: iudicium
Due to trimming, the endings of verses at fol. 14rb are missing, as well as verses at the top of fol. 14v cols a and b, and the beginning of verses at fol. 14va.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: Mozley (1933), pp. 235-238 (no. XIV).

msItem.locus: (fol. 15r col. a – col. b line 6)
msItem.author: Matthew, of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (extract: 1. 50).
msItem.incipit: religione sacer est uoce modestus, honesti
msItem.explicit: si liceat quatro querit habere gradu
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning (the first two verses are missing: the lower curve of a painted initial O which remains after timming is likely part of the letter O in the text's first verse: 'Orbis ad exemplum...'). Verses 42-44 are missing at the top of col. b due to trimming.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: PL 205.979-982; Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 121-122.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 64-67. Manuscript N.
WIC 13417 ('Orbis ad exemplum pape procedit honestas').

msItem.locus: (fol. 15r col. b line 6 – fol. 15v col. a line 12)
msItem.author: Matthew, of Vendôme, approximately 1130-
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (1.51).
msItem.incipit: Fulgurat in bello constancia Cesaris obstat
msItem.explicit: Roma, suo maius roma uidere capud.
msItem.note: The final verse reads 'Roma, suo maius ausa videre capud' in printed editions.
Due to trimming, the following verses or parts of verses are missing: the ends of verses 1-33 (fol. 15r), verses 34-36 and the beginnings of verses 37-48 (fol. 15v).

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: PL 205.979-982; Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 122-123.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 67-70. Manuscript N.

msItem.locus: (fol. 15v col. a line 13 – fol. 15v col. b line 32)
msItem.author: Matthew of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (1.52).
msItem.incipit: Purpurat eloquium, sensus festinat Ulixem
msItem.explicit: Consilio, Nestor mente, rigore Cato.
msItem.note: Due to trimming, the following verses or parts of verses are missing: the beginnings of verses 1-27 (fol. 15v col. a), and verses 28-30 (fol. 15v col. b).

listBibl.bibl: PL 205.979-982; Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 123-125.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 70-73. Manuscript N.

msItem.locus: (fol. 15v col. b lines 33–39)
msItem.author: Matthew of Vendôme
msItem.title: Ars versificatoria (1.53, verses 1-7)
msItem.incipit: Scurra uagus, parasitus edax, abiectio plebis
msItem.explicit: Forma Tersites, ad fraudes Argus, ad equum.
msItem.note: Imperfect at the end.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in: PL 205.983-984; Faral, Les arts poétiques, pp. 125.
Mathei Vindocinensis Opera, ed. F. Munari, vol. 3: Ars versificatoria (Rome, 1988), pp. 71-72. Manuscript N.

supportDesc.extent:
: ii + 16 leaves + ii (paper fly leaves)
c. 255 175 Measured from fol. 7, which has incurred less significant trimming than the other leaves; significant portions of most leaves were cut at the top, bottom or outer margins.
supportDesc.foliation: The old foliation running from 1 to 16 was rearranged in accordance with BQR 7 (1932), p. 133 and now runs in the following order: 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 10, 11v, 11r, 16, 7, 8, 5, 6, 12, 13v, 13r, 14, 15.
supportDesc.collation: Uncertain. Fols. 1-16 form a continuous (if incomplete) textual sequence: fol. 1 is a single leaf which remains from a now-missing quire; quire 2 (fols. 2, 3, 4, 9, 10, 11) is now made of three bifolia, and one or more central bifolia are now missing; fol. 16 is a single leaf which remains from a now-missing quire. Fols. 7, 8, 5, 6 constitute another continuous (but incomplete) sequence (fols. 7-8 are the central bifolium in a now incomplete quire, fols. 5 and 6 are now single leaves). Fols. 12, 13, 14, and 15 are isolated single leaves which do not constitute continuous textual sequences. See Mozley (1932) and Mozley (1933) for comments on the codicological structure.

layoutDesc.layout: 2 cols. of 42 lines; lead point ruling. Visible pricking on internal margin, near the gutter. First line of text above the top line. Ruled space c. 204 147

handDesc.handNote: Northern textualis: 'excellent bookhand of the thirteenth century' (Mozley (1932)).

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue and red two-line painted initials, some with penwork (red initials with blue penwork and blue initials with red penwork). Some guide letters (for example, fols. 10r and 11v).

binding.p: 19th-century Bodleian library binding. On the spine: 'Fragmenta poetica (Gul. Blesensis Alda &c.)'

history.provenance: Part of a series of unreferenced fragments arranged as palaeographical specimens, which was broken up in 1895: see Summary Catalogue no. 30479.

recordHist.source: Description by Clotilde Lemarié, Sept. 2024. Previously described: Summary Catalogue (1905). Summary Catalogue, vol. 5, p. 840

revisionDesc.change: James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
